document.title: Search Bar
document.description: Effortless search integration with Contentlayer and regex-based highlighting.

body.raw: # No-Setup Search Bar üöÄ One of the coolest things about **Pinexio** is its built-in search functionality. Thanks to **Contentlayer**, there is absolutely **no additional setup** required. Any `.mdx` file inside the `docs/` folder is automatically indexed and searchable. That means **no third-party libraries**, no extra indexing steps, and no configuration‚Äîjust write your documentation, and it‚Äôs instantly searchable! ## üîç How It Works The logic for searching and highlighting results is handled inside the **`SearchDialog`** component. Here‚Äôs how it works: 1. **Regex-based search**: The search input filters through all `.mdx` files and highlights matching text. 2. **Instant results**: Matches appear as you type, making navigation seamless. 3. **Keyboard shortcut support**: Press `Cmd + K` (Mac) or `Ctrl + K` (Windows/Linux) to open the search box instantly. 4. **Highlighted snippets**: The searched term is highlighted within the results. ## ‚ú® Key Features - **üìÇ No Configuration Needed** ‚Äì Contentlayer automatically makes all `.mdx` files searchable. - **‚ö° Instant Search** ‚Äì Type in the search box, and relevant results appear immediately. - **üé® Customizable Highlighting** ‚Äì The `highlightText` function ensures matched keywords stand out. - **‚å®Ô∏è Keyboard Shortcuts** ‚Äì Quick access using `Cmd + K` or `Ctrl + K`. - **üìå Contextual Snippets** ‚Äì The `getSnippet` function provides relevant text around the search term. ## üõ† Customization Developers can tweak the search experience by modifying: - `highlightText(text, searchTerm)`: Controls how search terms are highlighted. - `getSnippet(text, searchTerm, contextLength)`: Adjusts how much surrounding text is shown in results. - Styling: The UI is fully customizable with Tailwind CSS. ## üîß Code Snippet: Search Highlighting ```tsx function highlightText(text: string, searchTerm: string): React.ReactNode { if (!searchTerm) return text; const regex = new RegExp(`(${searchTerm})`, 'gi'); const parts = text.split(regex); return ( <> {parts.map((part, i) => regex.test(part) ? ( {part} ) : ( part ) )} ); } ``` ## üì∑ Visual Preview ![Search Bar Demo](#) ## üéØ Why This is Cool - **Developers don‚Äôt need to learn anything new**‚Äîjust write documentation, and it‚Äôs searchable. - **No indexing or database setup required**‚ÄîContentlayer handles everything automatically. - **Regex-based highlighting provides accurate and readable results**. - **Easily customizable for advanced search experiences**. This makes **Pinexio‚Äô search a true "No-Setup Search" solution**, saving time and effort while delivering a powerful experience for users. --- Want to enhance search further? Feel free to tweak the `SearchDialog` component to add fuzzy search, filters, or UI improvements. üöÄ

document.title: Theme
document.description: Learn how to customize the theme of your project with easy-to-use CSS variables for light and dark modes. This guide covers background and foreground colors, primary and secondary branding colors, and provides a clear structure for modifying the theme to suit your design needs.

body.raw:
# Theming in Your Project

## Overview

The theming system in your project is defined in `src/global.css`. It includes both **light** and **dark** themes, ensuring consistency throughout the application. Any changes to themes should be made in this file to maintain a unified styling approach.

## Understanding Foreground and Background

- **Background**: Represents the underlying surface color of an element, such as page backgrounds, cards, and modals.
- **Foreground**: Refers to everything that appears in front of the background, such as text, icons, and interactive elements.
- Maintaining a proper contrast between foreground and background ensures readability and accessibility.

## Primary and Secondary Colors

- **Primary Color**: The main color used in the UI, typically for branding, buttons, and highlights.
- **Secondary Color**: A complementary color used for less prominent elements, such as secondary buttons and backgrounds.

These colors are defined using **HSL variables**, making it easier to adjust them globally without modifying individual components.

## Where to Modify Themes

To update themes, modify the variables in `@layer base` inside `global.css`. Below is a highlighted snippet showing where developers should make changes:

```css
:root {
  /* Light Mode */
  --background: 0 0% 100%; /* White */
  --foreground: 0 0% 9%; /* Black */

  --primary: 222.2 47.4% 11.2%;
  --primary-foreground: 210 40% 98%;

  --secondary: 210 40% 96.1%;
  --secondary-foreground: 222.2 47.4% 11.2%;
}

.dark {
  /* Dark Mode */
  --background: 0 0% 4%; /* Very dark */
  --foreground: 0 0% 93%; /* Light text */

  --primary: 210 40% 98%;
  --primary-foreground: 222.2 47.4% 11.2%;

  --secondary: 217.2 32.6% 17.5%;
  --secondary-foreground: 210 40% 98%;
}
```

## Additional Theme Variables

Other UI components also use variables to define styling, including:

- **Borders** (`--border`, `--border-header`)
- **Status Colors** (`--success`, `--warning`, `--destructive`)
- **Components** (`--card`, `--popover`, `--button`)
- **Sidebar** (`--sidebar`, `--sidebar-active`)

Developers can customize these variables based on design requirements.

## Summary

- **Make theme changes in `src/global.css`**.
- **Understand foreground (text, icons) vs. background (page, containers)**.
- **Modify primary and secondary colors for branding consistency**.
- **Ensure contrast for accessibility**.
- **Leverage theme variables for easy customization**.

For further modifications, refer to the full theme structure in `global.css`. üöÄ

document.title: Button
document.description: A fully customizable, theme-aware button component with multiple variants and sizes, perfect for modern web applications. Ideal for developers looking for flexible UI elements in both light and dark modes.

body.raw:
# Button Component Documentation The **Button** component is a fully customizable button that supports multiple variants and size options. It is designed for modern, theme-aware applications that use CSS variables (defined in your global CSS) for light and dark modes. ## Preview and Code Snippet console.log("Tab clicked:", value)}> Preview Code
```tsx import React from "react"; import { Button } from "@/components/button"; export default function Example() { return (
); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ---------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ----------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------- | | `variant` | `"primary" \| "secondary" \| "outline" \| "none"` | `"outline"` | Defines the button style variant. Uses theme-aware CSS variables. | | `size` | `"xs" \| "sm" \| "md" \| "lg" \| "xl"` | `"sm"` | Controls the size of the button (affecting padding, font-size). | | `...props` | `React.ButtonHTMLAttributes` | ‚Äì | Supports all standard button attributes. |

document.title: Checkbox
document.description: A fully customizable, theme-aware checkbox component built with Tailwind CSS and React. Perfect for accessible and elegant form controls.

body.raw:
# Checkbox Component Documentation The **Checkbox** component is a flexible, accessible checkbox built using Tailwind CSS and React. It supports all native `` props and is fully theme-aware using your design tokens. It can be used standalone or composed inside custom labels. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code
```tsx import { Checkbox } from "@/components/checkbox"; export default function Example() { return (
); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ---------- | ------------------------------------------------ | ------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------- | | `id` | `string` | ‚Äì | Optional ID for the checkbox element. Auto-generated if omitted. | | `className`| `string` | `""` | Additional classes for the outer box. | | `disabled` | `boolean` | `false` | Disables the checkbox. | | `checked` | `boolean` | ‚Äì | Controls the checkbox state (used in controlled components). | | `defaultChecked` | `boolean` | ‚Äì | Initial checked state (for uncontrolled components). | | `...props` | `React.InputHTMLAttributes` | ‚Äì | All other native checkbox attributes like `onChange`, `name`, etc.| ## Styling - Fully theme-aware using Tailwind CSS classes like `peer-checked:bg-primary`. - Uses your design tokens (`border`, `primary`, etc.) to match your global theme. - Customize size, colors, or icons easily via Tailwind utility overrides. ## Example Usage ```tsx setAccepted(e.target.checked)} className="border-green-500" />

document.title: Dialog
document.description: The Dialog component is a customizable modal dialog that supports flexible content, triggers, and closing mechanisms with smooth animations.

body.raw:
# Dialog Component The `Dialog` component provides a customizable modal dialog with options for flexible content, triggers, and animations. It can be used for confirmations, form submissions, and other interactive UI elements. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code {(() => { const DialogExample = () => { const { useState } = React; const [open, setOpen] = useState(false); return (
Confirm Action Are you sure you want to proceed? Manual Dialog This is opened via setOpen.
); }; return ; })()} ```tsx import { Dialog, DialogTrigger, DialogContent, DialogCloseTrigger, DialogHeader, DialogTitle, DialogDescription, DialogFooter, } from '@/components/dialog'; export function DialogExample() { const [open, setOpen] = React.useState(false); return (
Confirm Action Are you sure you want to proceed? Manual Dialog This is opened via setOpen.
); } ``` ## Props ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ------------- | ------------------------ | ------- | ------------------------------------------------ | | `className` | string | - | Additional CSS classes for styling. | | `open` | boolean | - | Controls open state manually. | | `onOpenChange`| (open: boolean) => void | - | Callback to handle open state changes. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ----------- | ------- | ------- | ------------------------------------------------- | | `asChild` | boolean | `false` | Whether to render the trigger as a child element. | | `className` | string | - | Additional CSS classes. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | --------------------- | ------- | ------- | ------------------------------------------- | | `className` | string | - | Additional CSS classes for styling. | | `overlayClassName` | string | - | CSS classes for the overlay. | | `closeOnClickOutside` | boolean | `true` | Whether clicking outside closes the dialog. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ----------- | ------- | ------- | ------------------------------------------------------- | | `asChild` | boolean | `false` | Whether to render the close trigger as a child element. | | `className` | string | - | Additional CSS classes. | ### `` This is a container for the dialog header. ### `` This is the title of the dialog. ### `` This is a brief description of the dialog‚Äôs purpose. ### `` This is a container for footer actions (e.g., buttons).

document.title: Folder Tree
document.description: The FolderTree component is a customizable UI element for displaying and interacting with hierarchical file systems. Ideal for applications needing folder structures, it allows users to create collapsible directories and organize files with ease.

body.raw:
# FolderTree Component Documentation ## Overview The `FolderTree` component is a customizable folder structure UI component that allows users to represent and interact with a hierarchical file system. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code

layout.tsx

page.tsx

 ```tsx

layout.tsx

page.tsx

 ``` ## Props ### FolderTree Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ------------ | -------- | ------- | ----------------------------------- | | `className` | `string` | `-` | Additional classes for styling | | `indentSize` | `number` | `16` | Indentation size for nested folders | ### Folder Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ------------- | --------- | ------- | ------------------------------------ | | `element` | `string` | `-` | Name of the folder | | `defaultOpen` | `boolean` | `false` | Determines if the folder starts open | | `className` | `string` | `-` | Additional classes for styling | ### File Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ----------- | -------- | ------- | ------------------------------ | | `className` | `string` | `-` | Additional classes for styling | ## Usage Steps 1. **Wrap files and folders inside the `FolderTree` component.** 2. **Use the `Folder` component to create a collapsible directory.** 3. **Place `File` components inside `Folder` to represent files.** 4. **Use `defaultOpen` to control initial visibility.** ### Example ```tsx

Button.tsx

index.tsx

 ```

document.title: Input
document.description: A customizable and theme-aware input component with built-in support for variants, sizes, loading states, and error handling.

body.raw:
# Input Component Documentation The **Input** component is a fully customizable text input field that supports multiple variants, sizes, and states. It's ideal for form elements in modern, theme-aware applications. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code
```tsx import React from 'react'; import { Input } from '@/components/input'; export default function Example() { return (
); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |-------------|----------------------------------------------------|--------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------| | `variant` | `'outline' \| 'filled' \| 'none'` | `'outline'` | Controls the input's background and border style. | | `size` | `'xs' \| 'sm' \| 'md' \| 'lg' \| 'xl'` | `'sm'` | Controls the height and padding of the input. | | `fullWidth` | `boolean` | `false` | If true, the input takes up full width of its container. | | `isError` | `boolean` | `false` | Applies red border and ring to indicate error state. | | `isLoading` | `boolean` | `false` | Displays a spinning loader icon inside the input on the right. | | `...props` | `React.InputHTMLAttributes` | ‚Äì | Inherits all native input attributes. | ## Styling This input uses Tailwind CSS and `class-variance-authority` to manage style variants, making it easy to scale with design tokens or theming systems. ## Accessibility Ensure to associate `

document.title: Label
document.description: A flexible, theme-aware label component built with Tailwind CSS and class-variance-authority. Easily adaptable for any input, checkbox, or form element.

body.raw:
# Label Component Documentation The **Label** component is a lightweight, theme-aware, and variant-powered text label that can be used with form controls like inputs, checkboxes, radio buttons, and more. It's built using **Tailwind CSS** and **class-variance-authority (CVA)** for scalable styling logic. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code
```tsx import { Label } from "@/components/label"; import { Input } from "@/components/input"; export default function Example() { return (
); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------------|---------------------------------------------------------|-----------|-------------------------------------------------------------------| | `intent` | `"default" \| "muted" \| "error"` | `default` | Visual style of the label based on context or form state. | | `className`| `string` | `""` | Additional Tailwind utility classes to extend styles. | | `...props` | `React.LabelHTMLAttributes` | ‚Äì | All standard label attributes like `htmlFor`, `children`, etc. | ## Styling The component uses `class-variance-authority` to manage label style variants: ```ts const labelVariants = cva("text-sm font-medium leading-none", { variants: { intent: { default: "text-gray-900 dark:text-gray-100", muted: "text-gray-500 dark:text-gray-400", error: "text-red-600 dark:text-red-400", }, }, defaultVariants: { intent: "default", }, }); ``` You can customize these classes to match your design system. ## Usage Example ```tsx ``` --- Use the `Label` component for accessible, consistent labeling in all your forms. It pairs perfectly with custom input components like `Checkbox`, `Input`, or `TextArea`.

document.title: Menu
document.description: The Menu component provides a flexible dropdown menu with support for both standard and autocomplete functionality. It allows users to toggle visibility, select items, and filter results dynamically.

body.raw:
# Menu Component The `Menu` component provides a dropdown menu with options for standard and autocomplete menus. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code {(() => { const { useState } = React; const [search, setSearch] = useState(""); const menuItems = [ { label: "Home", icon: "üè†" }, { label: "Settings", icon: "‚öôÔ∏è" }, { label: "Profile", icon: "üë§" }, { label: "Logout", icon: "üö™" }, ]; const filteredItems = menuItems.filter((item) => item.label.toLowerCase().includes(search.toLowerCase()) ); return (
Menu üè† Home ‚öôÔ∏è Settings Search Menu setSearch(e.target.value)} className="w-full p-2 border-b border-gray-300 dark:border-gray-600 focus:outline-none" /> {filteredItems.map((item) => ( {item.icon} {item.label} ))}
); })()} ```tsx import { useState } from 'react'; import { Menu, MenuTrigger, PopMenu, MenuItem } from '@/components/menu'; export default function Example() { const [search, setSearch] = useState(''); const menuItems = [ { label: 'Home', icon: 'üè†' }, { label: 'Settings', icon: '‚öôÔ∏è' }, { label: 'Profile', icon: 'üë§' }, { label: 'Logout', icon: 'üö™' }, ]; const filteredItems = menuItems.filter((item) => item.label.toLowerCase().includes(search.toLowerCase()) ); return (
Menu üè† {' '} Home ‚öôÔ∏è {' '} Settings Search Menu setSearch(e.target.value)} className="w-full p-2 border-b border-gray-300 dark:border-gray-600 focus:outline-none" /> {filteredItems.map((item) => ( {item.icon} {' '} {item.label} ))}
); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ----------- | ------------------------- | ------- | --------------------------------------- | | `className` | `string` | `''` | Additional CSS classes. | | `open` | `boolean` | `false` | Controls the visibility of the menu. | | `setOpen` | `(open: boolean) => void` | `-` | Function to toggle the menu state. | | `children` | `ReactNode` | `-` | The content inside the menu components. | ## Usage Steps 1. Import the `Menu`, `MenuTrigger`, `PopMenu`, and `MenuItem` components. 2. Wrap the menu items inside the `Menu` component. 3. Use `MenuTrigger` to create a clickable button for toggling the menu. 4. Wrap menu items inside `PopMenu` for display. 5. Optionally, include an input field inside `PopMenu` to create an autocomplete menu. ### Example ```tsx Options ‚öôÔ∏è {' '} Settings üö™ {' '} Logout ```

document.title: NavMenu Documentation
document.description: Detailed usage guide for the NavMenu component.

body.raw:
# NavMenu The `NavMenu` component is a flexible and customizable navigation menu that supports dynamic positioning based on screen space. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code
Getting started
    Overview of components and usage. Learn how to install dependencies.
Components
    Usage of button component. Learn how to use cards effectively.
Resources
    Read insightful blogs and tutorials. Join discussions and share knowledge.
```tsx import { useState } from 'react'; import { Menu, MenuTrigger, PopMenu, MenuItem } from '@/components/menu'; export default function Example() { return (
Getting started
    Overview of components and usage. Learn how to install dependencies.
Components
    Usage of button component. Learn how to use cards effectively.
Resources
    Read insightful blogs and tutorials. Join discussions and share knowledge.
); } ``` ## Props ### `NavMenu` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ---------- | ----- | ------- | ----------- | | `position` | `up` | `down` | `'down'` | ### `NavMenuItem` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ----------- | ------------ | ------- | -------------------------------------------------- | | `onClick` | `() => void` | `-` | Function to execute when the menu item is clicked. | | `className` | `string` | `-` | Additional class names for styling. | ## Positioning Behavior The `position` prop controls whether the menu expands upwards or downwards. If not specified, the menu dynamically adjusts based on available screen space. ### Example with `position="up"` ```tsx Settings Logout ``` ## Custom Styling You can extend the `NavMenu` styles using Tailwind CSS or custom class names. ```tsx Profile ``` ## Accessibility - `aria-expanded` is automatically managed for toggling the menu. - Uses `role="menu"` and `role="menuitem"` for proper navigation.

document.title: Note
document.description: The Note component is designed to display contextual messages in various styles, including info, success, warning, and more. Perfect for alerting users or providing helpful tips in your UI. Easily customizable with support for icons and additional styles.

body.raw:
# Note Component The `Note` component is used to display contextual messages with different styles based on the type of note. ## Preview and Code Snippet console.log("Tab clicked:", value)}> Preview Code
This is an informational note. This is a success message. This is a warning message. This is an Normal message.
```tsx import { Note } from '@/components/note'; export default function Example() { return (
This is an informational note. This is a success message. This is a warning message. This is an alert message. This is a helpful tip.
); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ----------- | -------------------------------------------------------------- | -------- | --------------------------------- | | `type` | `none` \| `info` \| `warning` \| `alert` \| `success` \| `tip` | `'none'` | Determines the style of the note. | | `className` | `string` | `''` | Additional CSS classes. | | `hideIcon` | `boolean` | `false` | Hides the note icon when `true`. | | `children` | `ReactNode` | `-` | The content of the note. | ## Usage Steps 1. Import the `Note` component from your components folder. 2. Use the `type` prop to specify the type of note. 3. Optionally, use `hideIcon` to hide the icon. 4. Add your message inside the `` component. ### Example ```tsx Success without an icon! ``` This component helps in displaying contextual messages effectively in your UI.

document.title: Popover
document.description: The Popover component provides a floating UI container that can be triggered by clicking or hovering over elements. It supports smart positioning, click-outside detection, and customizable content.

body.raw:
# Popover Component The `Popover` component provides a flexible and responsive floating container that can be triggered to appear around any element. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code {(() => { return (

Simple popover content.

Feedback

document.title: Search Button
document.description: The SearchButton component provides a customizable search button with a command key icon (‚åòK) for modern web applications. It supports multiple size variants and is theme-aware, making it perfect for light and dark mode designs.

body.raw:
# SearchButton Component Documentations The **SearchButton** component is a highly customizable search button that displays a command key icon (‚åòK) and supports multiple size variants. It is designed for modern, theme-aware applications that use CSS variables (defined in your global CSS) for light and dark modes. ## Preview and Code Snippet console.log("Tab clicked:", value)}> Preview Code
```tsx import React from "react"; import SearchButton from "@/components/search-button.tsx"; export default function Example() { return (
); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ------------- | ----------------------------------------------- | -------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `placeholder` | `string` | `"Search Documentation.."` | The text displayed in the button. | | `size` | `"xs" \| "sm" \| "md" \| "lg" \| "xl"` | `"md"` | Controls the size of the button (affecting padding, font-size, icon size). | | `...props` | `React.ButtonHTMLAttributes` | ‚Äì | All standard button props are supported. |

document.title: Select
document.description: The Select component is a customizable dropdown for single and multiple selections, featuring search, controlled/uncontrolled modes, and flexible UI customization.

body.raw:
# Select Component The `Select` component provides an intuitive dropdown menu that supports both single and multiple selections with an optional search input. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code {(() => { const { useState } = React; const options = [ "apple", "banana", "blueberry", "grapes", "pineapple", "mango", "strawberry", "orange", "kiwi", "watermelon", "peach", "pear" ]; const [selectedFruits, setSelectedFruits] = useState(''); const [selectedFruit, setSelectedFruit] = useState(''); return (
); })()} ```tsx import { useState } from 'react'; import { Select, SelectValue, SelectContent, SelectItem, } from '@/components/select'; export const SelectSingle = () => { const [selectedFruits, setSelectedFruit] = useState('apple'); const handleSelect = (value: string | string[]) => { setSelectedFruit(value as string); }; return ( ); }; ``` ## Props ### ` console.log(value)}> Apple Banana ```

document.title: Sidebar
document.description: The Sidebar component is a customizable and flexible navigation panel that supports collapsible menus, nested links, and icons. Ideal for applications, dashboards, and documentation sites requiring structured navigation.

body.raw:
# Sidebar Component Documentation The **Sidebar** component is a flexible and customizable navigation panel. It supports collapsible menus, nested links, and icons, making it ideal for documentation sites, dashboards, and applications with structured navigation. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code Documentation } label="Getting Started"/> } label="Configuration"/>
v1.0.0
{

Main Content

}
 ```tsx import { SidebarProvider, Sidebar, SidebarHeader, SidebarTrigger, SidebarHeaderTitle, SidebarContent, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuItem, SidebarFooter, NestedLink } from "@/components/sidebar"; import { BookOpen, Settings, FileText } from "lucide-react"; export default function Example() { return ( Documentation } label="Getting Started" href="/docs/getting-started" /> } label="Configuration" href="/docs/configuration" />
v1.0.0
 ); } ``` ## Props ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |---------------------|----------------|-----------|-------------| | children | React.ReactNode | - | The child components of the provider. | | defaultOpen | boolean | true | Determines if the sidebar is open by default. | | defaultSide | 'left' \| 'right' | 'left' | The default position of the sidebar. | | defaultMaxWidth | number | 280 | The maximum width of the sidebar in pixels. | | showIconsOnCollapse | boolean | true | Determines if icons should be shown when the sidebar is collapsed. | | mobileView | boolean | true | Enables mobile-specific sidebar behavior. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------------|-------------------|---------|-------------| | className | string | - | Additional CSS classes for styling. | | children | React.ReactNode | - | The child elements inside the sidebar. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------------|-------------------|---------|-------------| | children | React.ReactNode | - | The header content of the sidebar. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------------|-------------------|---------|-------------| | children | React.ReactNode | - | The main content area of the sidebar. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------------|-------------------|---------|-------------| | children | React.ReactNode | - | The footer section of the sidebar. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------------|-------------------|---------|-------------| | children | React.ReactNode | - | The navigation menu inside the sidebar. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |--------------|-------------------|------------|-------------| | icon | React.ReactNode | - | An optional icon to display in the menu item. | | label | string | - | The text label for the menu item. | | href | string | - | The link to navigate to. | | children | React.ReactNode | - | Sub-menu items if applicable. | | isActive | boolean | undefined | Manually set active state. | | defaultOpen | boolean | false | Whether the submenu is open by default. | | alwaysOpen | boolean | false | Keeps the submenu permanently open. | | isCollapsable | boolean | false | Whether the submenu can be collapsed. | ### `` | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------------|-------------------|---------|-------------| | children | React.ReactNode | - document.title: Steps
document.description: The Steps component is designed to visually represent a multi-step process. It supports both horizontal and vertical layouts, making it perfect for onboarding, wizards, and process visualizations.

body.raw:
# Steps Component Documentation The **Steps** component provides a structured way to represent a multi-step process. It supports both horizontal and vertical layouts, making it ideal for onboarding flows, wizards, and process visualizations. ## Preview and Code Snippet Preview Code Step 1: Fork the Repository

Visit our GitHub repository and click the "Fork" button to create your own copy.

Fork the Repository on GitHub
Step 2: Clone the Repository

Use the following command to clone the repository to your local machine:

git clone https://github.com/your-repo/example.git
 Step 3: Install Dependencies

Navigate into the project directory and run:

npm install
 ```tsx import { Steps, Step, StepTitle, StepContent } from "@/components/steps"; export default function Example() { return ( Step 1: Fork the Repository

Visit our GitHub repository and click the "Fork" button to create your own copy.

Fork the Repository on GitHub
Step 2: Clone the Repository

Use the following command to clone the repository to your local machine:

git clone https://github.com/your-repo/example.git
 Step 3: Install Dependencies

Navigate into the project directory and run:

npm install
 ); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | ------------------ | -------------------- | --------- | ---------------------------------------------------------- | | `contentPosition` | `"right" \| "below"` | `"below"` | Defines whether the content appears to the right or below. | | `className` | `string` | `""` | Custom class for styling the steps container. | | `titleClassName` | `string` | `""` | Custom class for styling the step title. | | `contentClassName` | `string` | `""` | Custom class for styling the step content. | | `lineClassName` | `string` | `""` | Custom class for styling the connector line. | | `numberClassName` | `string` | `""` | Custom class for styling the step number circle. | The **Steps** component is highly flexible and allows for styling customization to fit various UI requirements.

document.title: Syntax Highlighter
document.description: The Syntax Highlighter component offers customizable and interactive syntax highlighting for code snippets, supporting multiple languages, tabs for variations, and a copy-to-clipboard feature.

body.raw:
# Syntax Highlighter Component Documentation

The **Syntax Highlighter** component provides a customizable and interactive way to display code snippets with syntax highlighting. It supports multiple tabs for different code variations and includes a copy-to-clipboard feature.

## Preview and Code Snippet

<Tabs defaultValue="preview" size="sm" className="w-full">
  <TabsList className="grid w-full md:w-[30%] grid-cols-2">
    <Tab value="preview">Preview</Tab>
    <Tab value="code">Code</Tab>
  </TabsList>
  <TabsContent value="preview">
    <Preview>
      <CustomSyntaxHighlighter
        className="xs:w-auto md:w-[60%]"
        themeMode="dark"
        tabs={{
          JavaScript: { syntax: "console.log('Hello, world!');", language: "javascript" },
          Python: { syntax: "print('Hello, world!')", language: "python" }
        }}
        indicatorColor="bg-blue-500"
      />
    </Preview>
  </TabsContent>
  <TabsContent value="code">
    ```tsx
    import CustomSyntaxHighlighter from "@/components/syntax-highlighter";

    export default function Example() {
      return (
        <CustomSyntaxHighlighter
          themeMode="dark"
          tabs={{
            JavaScript: { syntax: "console.log('Hello, world!');", language: "javascript" },
            Python: { syntax: "print('Hello, world!')", language: "python" }
          }}
          indicatorColor="bg-blue-500"
        />
      );
    }
    ```

  </TabsContent>
</Tabs>

## Props

| Prop             | Type                                                    | Default           | Description                                                                            |
| ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `tabs`           | `Record<string, { syntax: string; language?: string }>` | `{}`              | An object where keys represent tab names and values contain code and language details. |
| `className`      | `string`                                                | `undefined`       | Custom CSS classes for additional styling.                                             |
| `themeMode`      | `'light' \| 'dark'`                                     | `'dark'`          | Controls the theme mode of the syntax highlighter.                                     |
| `lightTheme`     | `Record<string, any>`                                   | `oneLight`        | Custom theme for light mode.                                                           |
| `darkTheme`      | `Record<string, any>`                                   | `oneDark`         | Custom theme for dark mode.                                                            |
| `indicatorColor` | `string`                                                | `'bg-yellow-500'` | Custom color for the active tab indicator.                                             |

document.title: Tabs
document.description: The Tabs component provides a customizable and smooth tab navigation system, supporting multiple sizes and theme-aware applications, perfect for modern UIs with light and dark modes.

body.raw:
# Tabs Component Documentation The **Tabs** component is a customizable tab system that supports multiple sizes and provides a smooth transition effect. It is designed for modern, theme-aware applications that use CSS variables (defined in your global CSS) for light and dark modes. ## Preview and Code Snippet console.log("Tab clicked:", value)}> Preview Code Account Password

Account Settings

Manage your account settings and preferences.

Password Settings

Change your password and security settings.

 ```tsx import { Tabs, TabsContent, TabsList, Tab } from "@/components/tabs"; export default function Example() { return ( Account Password

Account Settings

Manage your account settings and preferences.

Password Settings

Change your password and security settings.

 ); } ``` ## Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | --------------- | -------------------------------------- | ----------- | ------------------------------------------------- | | `defaultValue` | `string` | `""` | The initial active tab when the component mounts. | | `value` | `string` | `""` | The controlled value of the active tab. | | `onValueChange` | `(value: string) => void` | `undefined` | Callback function when the active tab changes. | | `onTabClick` | `(value: string) => void` | `undefined` | Callback function when a tab is clicked. | | `size` | `"xs" \| "sm" \| "md" \| "lg" \| "xl"` | `"md"` | Controls the size of the tab buttons. | | `...props` | `React.HTMLAttributes` | ‚Äì | Supports all standard `div` attributes. |

document.title: Setting Up Metadata for SEO and Social Sharing
document.description: Learn how to configure metadata for SEO and social media sharing in your Next.js documentation site.

body.raw:
# Setting Up Metadata for SEO and Social Sharing Proper metadata configuration is crucial for making your documentation site discoverable on search engines and look great when shared on social media. This guide will walk you through setting up metadata in your **Next.js** project. ## Why Metadata Matters - Improves search engine rankings (SEO) - Ensures rich previews when shared on Twitter, LinkedIn, and Facebook - Helps define authorship and branding ## Configuring Metadata in Next.js Next.js provides built-in support for metadata configuration via the [`metadata` API](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/functions/generate-metadata). ### Step 1: Create or Change Existing Metadata Configuration File Inside your project, create a new file at:

meta.tsx

 ### Example JSON ```tsx export const meta = { metadataBase: new URL('https://pinexio.vercel.app'), title: 'Pinexio - Documentation Template', description: 'A customizable open-source documentation template built with Next.js.', authors: [{ name: 'Sanjay Rajeev' }], keywords: [ 'Pinexio', 'documentation template', 'Next.js', 'React', 'JavaScript', ], publisher: 'Sanjay Rajeev', creator: 'Sanjay Rajeev', openGraph: { type: 'website', title: 'Pinexio - Documentation Template', description: 'A customizable open-source documentation template built with Next.js.', images: [ { url: '/og_image.png', width: 1200, height: 630, alt: 'Pinexio Documentation Template', }, ], }, twitter: { card: 'summary_large_image', title: 'Pinexio - Documentation Template', description: 'A customizable open-source documentation template built with Next.js.', images: ['/og_image.png'], creator: '@sanjayrajeev', }, alternates: { canonical: 'https://pinexio.vercel.app', }, robots: 'index, follow', hreflang: { en: 'https://pinexio.vercel.app', }, }; ``` ### Step 2: Verify Your Metadata Once you've set up the metadata, verify it using: - [Google Rich Results Test](https://search.google.com/test/rich-results) - [Twitter Card Validator](https://cards-dev.twitter.com/validator) - [Facebook Sharing Debugger](https://developers.facebook.com/tools/debug/) ## Learn More For more advanced metadata options, check out the [Next.js Metadata API](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/functions/generate-metadata). --- This setup ensures your documentation pages are well-optimized for search engines and social media. üöÄ

document.title: Sidebar Customization
document.description: A guide to modifying the sidebar navigation in your documentation template.

body.raw:
# Sidebar Customization The sidebar navigation in this documentation template is defined in the `config/sidebar.tsx` file. Developers can easily modify the sidebar structure by adding, updating, or removing items in this configuration. ## Folder Structure The sidebar configuration is stored in the `config` directory:

sidebar.tsx

introduction.mdx

installation.mdx

theme.mdx

search-bar.mdx

Sidebar.tsx

 ## Editing Sidebar Navigation To customize the sidebar, open `config/sidebar.tsx` and modify the `sidebarNav` array. ### Sidebar Structure Each sidebar item follows this structure: ```tsx { title: string; // Display title icon?: JSX.Element; // Optional icon component href?: string; // Optional link if there are no sub-pages pages?: { title: string; // Sub-page title href: string; // Sub-page link }[]; } ``` ### Adding a New Sidebar Section If you want to add a new section, append an object to the `sidebarNav` array: ```tsx { title: "New Section", icon: , // Use any icon pages: [ { title: "New Page", href: "/docs/new-section/new-page", } ] } ``` ### Adding a Single Page Without Sub-Pages To add a single page (without dropdown sub-pages): ```tsx { title: "Standalone Page", icon: , href: "/docs/standalone-page", pages: [] // Keep empty } ``` ### Removing an Existing Section Simply remove the corresponding object from the `sidebarNav` array. ### Updating an Existing Section Modify the `title`, `href`, or `pages` array for an existing item. ## Where is the Sidebar Rendered? The sidebar is typically used inside a `Sidebar.tsx` component inside the `components` directory. Ensure that this component correctly maps over the `sidebarNav` array and renders it dynamically. ## Summary - The sidebar structure is defined in `config/sidebar.tsx`. - Each section contains a `title`, optional `icon`, and `pages` array. - To modify the sidebar, update the `sidebarNav` array. - Changes are automatically reflected in the sidebar component. - This is a simple modification that can be done quickly. This guide should help developers easily navigate and modify the sidebar for their documentation.

document.title: Table of Contents (TOC) Customization
document.description: A guide to modifying the Table of Contents (TOC) in your documentation template.

body.raw:
# Table of Contents (TOC) Customization The Table of Contents (TOC) in this documentation template is defined in the `config/toc.tsx` file. It provides quick reference links on the right side of each documentation page, allowing users to navigate sections efficiently. ## Folder Structure The TOC configuration is stored in the `config` directory:

toc.tsx

introduction.mdx

installation.mdx

button.mdx

Toc.tsx

 ## Editing Table of Contents (TOC) The TOC is structured as an object where each key represents a unique `slug` corresponding to a documentation page. These keys map to an array of TOC sections. ### TOC Structure Each TOC entry follows this format: ```tsx 'page-slug': [ { title: string; // Section title href: string; // Link to the section pages?: { title: string; // Sub-section title href: string; // Link to the subsection }[]; } ] ``` The `page-slug` is derived from the `slug` metadata of the respective documentation page. ### Example TOC Configuration ```tsx export const TocData = { 'getting-started/introduction': [ { title: 'Welcome to Pinexio', href: '/docs/getting-started/introduction#welcome-to-pinexio', pages: [ { title: 'Why Choose Pinexio', href: '/docs/getting-started/introduction#why-choose-pinexio', }, { title: 'What Makes Pinexio Special', href: '/docs/getting-started/introduction#what-makes-pinexio-special', }, ], }, ], 'components/button': [ { title: 'Preview & Code Snippet', href: '/docs/components/button#preview-and-code-snippet', }, { title: 'Props', href: '/docs/components/button#props', }, ], }; ``` ### Adding a New TOC Entry To add a new TOC entry, insert a new key-value pair in `TocData`: ```tsx 'new-section/page-slug': [ { title: "New Section", href: "/docs/new-section#new-section", } ] ``` ### Removing a TOC Entry Simply delete the corresponding key from `TocData`. ## Where is the TOC Rendered? The TOC is used in the `toc.tsx` component, which dynamically retrieves TOC data based on the `slug` value of the active page. #### TOC Component (`src/components/toc.tsx`)

toc.tsx

 ## Summary - The TOC structure is defined in `config/toc.tsx`. - Each TOC key corresponds to a unique `slug` for matching documentation pages. - TOC modifications update the right-side quick reference links. - The `toc.tsx` component dynamically retrieves and displays TOC data. - Changes are simple and allow for easy customization. This guide ensures developers can efficiently modify and maintain the TOC structure for their documentation.

document.title: Installation
document.description: Complete installation guide for setting up Revi error monitoring in your development environment, including backend, dashboard, and SDK components.

body.raw:
# Installation Guide Welcome to the complete installation guide for Revi! This guide covers setting up the full Revi stack, including the backend API, dashboard, and SDK for comprehensive error monitoring and session replay. ## Architecture Overview Revi consists of three main components: - **Backend API**: Encore.ts-based service for data collection and storage - **Dashboard**: Next.js web application for monitoring and analytics - **SDK**: Client-side JavaScript library for error capture and session recording Step 1: Clone the Repository
Clone the Revi repository to get started:
```sh git clone https://github.com/your-org/revi.git cd revi ```
Step 2: Set Up the Backend
The Revi backend is built with Encore.ts and requires PostgreSQL. **Install Encore CLI:** ```sh curl -L https://encore.dev/install.sh | bash ``` **Navigate to the backend directory:** ```sh cd backend ``` **Install dependencies:** **Set up environment variables:** ```sh cp .env.example .env # Edit .env with your database credentials ``` **Run database migrations:** ```sh encore db migrate ``` **Start the backend server:** ```sh encore run ``` The backend will be available at `http://localhost:4000`
Step 3: Set Up the Dashboard
The dashboard is a Next.js application that provides the web interface. **Navigate to the dashboard directory:** ```sh cd ../dashboard ``` **Install dependencies:** **Configure environment variables:** ```sh cp .env.example .env ``` Edit `.env` with your configuration: ```env DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/revi NEXT_PUBLIC_REVI_API_URL=http://localhost:4000 BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=your-auth-secret-here GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your-google-oauth-client-id GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-google-oauth-secret ``` **Set up the database schema:** ```sh npx drizzle-kit push ``` **Start the dashboard:** The dashboard will be available at `http://localhost:3000`
Step 4: Build and Test the SDK
The SDK is the client-side library that captures errors and user sessions. **Navigate to the SDK directory:** ```sh cd ../sdk ``` **Install dependencies:** **Build the SDK:** **Test the SDK (optional):** **Create a test application:** ```sh cd examples/react-demo npm install npm start ```
Step 5: Create Your First Project

Now that everything is running, create your first monitoring project:

1. Open the dashboard at `http://localhost:3000` 2. Sign in with Google OAuth or create an account 3. Click "Create New Project" and fill in the details 4. Copy the generated API key 5. Use the API key in your applications with the Revi SDK **Your project structure should look like this:**

encore.app

package.json

package.json

.env

package.json

dist/
## Environment Configuration ### Backend Environment Variables ```env # Database DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/revi # API Settings PORT=4000 NODE_ENV=development # Optional: External integrations SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL=https://hooks.slack.com/services/... DISCORD_WEBHOOK_URL=https://discord.com/api/webhooks/... ``` ### Dashboard Environment Variables ```env # Database (same as backend) DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/revi # Application URLs NEXT_PUBLIC_APP_URL=http://localhost:3000 NEXT_PUBLIC_REVI_API_URL=http://localhost:4000 NEXT_PUBLIC_REVI_PROJECT_ID=1 # Authentication BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=your-long-random-secret-key-here GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your-google-oauth-client-id GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-google-oauth-client-secret ``` ## Development Workflow ### Starting the Full Stack ```sh # Terminal 1: Start the backend cd backend && encore run # Terminal 2: Start the dashboard cd dashboard && npm run dev # Terminal 3: Build/watch the SDK (if developing) cd sdk && npm run build:watch ``` ### Database Management **Reset the database:** ```sh cd backend && encore db reset cd dashboard && npx drizzle-kit push ``` **View database contents:** ```sh cd backend && encore db shell ``` ### Building for Production **Backend:** ```sh cd backend && encore build ``` **Dashboard:** ```sh cd dashboard && npm run build ``` **SDK:** ```sh cd sdk && npm run build ``` ## Troubleshooting ### Common Issues **Port conflicts:** - Backend: Change port in `encore.app` or set `PORT` environment variable - Dashboard: Use `npm run dev -- -p 3001` to use a different port **Database connection errors:** - Ensure PostgreSQL is running - Check `DATABASE_URL` in both backend and dashboard `.env` files - Run database migrations: `encore db migrate` and `npx drizzle-kit push` **Authentication not working:** - Verify Google OAuth credentials are correct - Ensure `BETTER_AUTH_SECRET` is set and matches between components - Check that callback URLs are configured in Google Console **SDK not capturing errors:** - Verify the backend is running and accessible - Check browser network tab for API call errors - Ensure the API key is correct and the project exists ### Getting Help - **Documentation**: Continue reading the guides in this documentation - **GitHub Issues**: Report bugs and request features - **Discord Community**: Join our developer community for real-time help üéâ **Congratulations!** You now have a complete Revi installation running locally. Continue to the [Quick Start Guide](/docs/getting-started/quick-start) to integrate Revi into your first application.

document.title: Introduction
document.description: Revi is an open-source error monitoring and session replay platform that helps developers debug production issues faster. Capture every error, record user sessions, and get the context you need to fix problems before they impact your users.

body.raw:
# Welcome to **Revi**

## The Complete Error Monitoring & Session Replay Platform

Welcome to **Revi** - the open-source error monitoring solution that gives you complete visibility into your application's health! üîç Revi captures every error, records user sessions, and provides the context you need to debug issues faster than ever before.

## Why Choose Revi?

Stop losing sleep over production bugs. With **Revi**, you get instant alerts when things go wrong and complete session replays showing exactly what your users experienced. Here's why developers love Revi:

- **Complete Error Tracking** üö®: Automatically capture JavaScript errors, unhandled promises, network failures, and custom exceptions with detailed stack traces and user context.
- **Full Session Replay** üìπ: Watch exactly what users did leading up to errors with complete DOM reconstruction, click tracking, and form interactions.
- **Real-time Monitoring** ‚ö°: Get instant notifications when errors occur with intelligent alerting that reduces noise and focuses on what matters.
- **Privacy by Design** üîí: Built-in data masking, GDPR compliance, and configurable privacy controls to protect sensitive user information.
- **Developer-First Experience** üíª: Easy integration with any JavaScript framework, comprehensive SDKs, and detailed documentation.

## What Makes Revi Special?

Revi solves the frustrating problem of debugging production issues without context. Traditional error tracking tells you *what* went wrong, but Revi shows you *exactly how* it happened.

Here's what makes Revi different:

- **Zero Configuration Setup**: Add our SDK to your app in under 5 minutes and start capturing errors immediately
- **Complete User Journey**: See the full user session leading up to errors - every click, scroll, input, and navigation
- **Intelligent Error Grouping**: Advanced algorithms group similar errors and detect patterns automatically
- **Production-Ready Performance**: <50ms overhead with smart sampling and efficient data compression
- **Open Source & Self-Hostable**: Full control over your data with optional cloud hosting for convenience

## Core Features

### üîç Error Monitoring
- **Automatic Error Capture**: JavaScript errors, unhandled promises, network failures
- **Custom Error Tracking**: Manual error reporting with custom tags and context
- **Detailed Stack Traces**: Source map support for production debugging
- **User Context**: Browser info, user agents, custom user identification

### üìπ Session Replay
- **Complete DOM Recording**: Pixel-perfect recreation of user sessions
- **User Interaction Tracking**: Clicks, scrolls, form inputs, and navigation
- **Console Log Capture**: Debug information from the user's browser
- **Network Request Monitoring**: API calls, response times, and failure tracking

### ‚ö° Performance Monitoring
- **Core Web Vitals**: LCP, FID, CLS tracking and optimization insights
- **Resource Timing**: Track slow assets and optimize loading performance
- **Custom Performance Marks**: Monitor business-critical user actions

### üîß Developer Tools
- **Source Map Support**: Debug minified production code with original source references
- **Release Tracking**: Associate errors with specific deployments and versions
- **Custom Dashboards**: Build monitoring views tailored to your team's needs
- **Integrations**: Slack, Discord, PagerDuty, Jira, and more

## Technology Stack

Revi is built with modern, battle-tested technologies:

- **Frontend SDK**: Vanilla JavaScript with React, Vue, Angular, and Svelte integrations
- **Backend API**: Node.js with TypeScript and Encore.ts framework
- **Database**: PostgreSQL with advanced indexing for fast queries
- **Real-time Updates**: WebSocket connections for live error streaming
- **Dashboard**: Next.js 15 with Tailwind CSS for responsive design

## Deployment Options

- **üåê Revi Cloud**: Hosted solution with 99.9% uptime SLA and global CDN
- **üè† Self-Hosted**: Deploy on your infrastructure with Docker and Kubernetes support
- **üîß Hybrid**: Keep sensitive data on-premise while leveraging cloud analytics

---

Revi is **open-source** under the MIT license, which means you can use it freely, modify it, and contribute back to the community. Whether you're running a startup or an enterprise application, Revi scales with your needs.

## Ready to Stop Debugging Blind?

Join thousands of developers who've eliminated production debugging frustration with Revi. Get started in minutes with our comprehensive SDKs and intuitive dashboard.

```bash
npm install revi-monitor
```

---

Need help getting started? Check out our comprehensive guides, join our Discord community, or open an issue on GitHub. We're here to help you build more reliable applications! üöÄ

[Quick Start Guide](/docs/getting-started/quick-start) | [SDK Documentation](/docs/sdk) | [GitHub Repository](https://github.com/your-org/revi)

---

_Debug faster. Ship with confidence. üõ°Ô∏è_
